The Cue Editor

Click on an existing cue button to edit it, or click on + Add Cue to create a new cue button.

Cue Settings

Each cue can be configured with settings for display and playback. The following options are available for every cue:

Cue Title
The name of the cue, which will appear on the button and in the queue/playback controls.

Subgroup
If assigned to a subgroup, playing this cue will fade out any other cue in the same subgroup. Similarly, if this cue is playing and a different cue in the same subgroup is played, this cue will fade out.

If you do not assign a subgroup this cue will play on top, regardless of what else is playing.

Loop Cue
You can set this cue to loop by default. You can always change the loop state of a playing cue on the playback interface.

Fade In
By default, cues will either fade in or start at full volume, depending on the board's current setting. Instead, you can specify that this specific cue should always (or never) fade in.

Delete Cue (delete)
You can click on the delete icon to remove a cue from the project. This will not affect any media files attached to the cue.

Assigning Media

A cue will need at least one media file assigned in order to play. If multiple media files are assigned, one will play at random each time the cue is played (but the same one won't play twice in a row). If no media files are assigned, the button will be disabled in player mode or have a warning icon (warning) in editor mode.

Cue Audio File(s)
This area at the bottom of the cue editor lists the audio files assigned to the cue. You can remove an assigned file by clicking on the removal icon (×).

Project Media
Here you will see a list of all the media files in the project that can be assigned to the cue. Select a filename and click << Assign File to Cue (or double-click the filename) to assign it.

You can add new media files to the project by clicking on + Add Files.

NOTE: Any media files added from this screen will automatically be assigned to the current cue.

Media Filter
If your project has a lot of media files, you can use the filter box below the media list to find a specific file. Type anything into the box to start filtering files by name.

Subgroups

Synthea utilizes the concept of subgroups to manage concurrent playback of cues in a project that might utilize any combination of music, ambient audio, and discrete sound effects. If your project has a "board type" set, all new cues will default to that subgroup.

Concurrency
By default, all cues want to play on top of one another, which works well for layering audio and creating dynamic soundscapes. Any cue without a subgroup will layer on top of other currently-playing cues (i.e. concurrency).

Exclusivity
Some types of cues shouldn't be play on top of each other. For example, playing a music track should seamlessly replace the music track that's currently playing, and itself be replaced by another. In short: there should only be one music track playing at any given time (i.e. exclusivity).

Every Synthea subgroup creates an exclusivity set, so playing a cue in that subgroup will replace any currently-playing cues in that same subgroup. Cues in other subgroups, and cues without subgroups, will not be affected.

SUBGROUP PLAYBACK EXAMPLE:
Cue Played Subgroup Effect
Happy Music Music Track fades in automatically and plays
Gentle Waves Ambient Track plays concurrently over music
Thunderclap none Track plays concurrently over all others
Stronger Waves Ambient Track cross-fades with previous "ambient" track to replace it
Medium Rain Rain Track plays concurrently over all others
Intense Music Music Track cross-fades with previous "music" track to replace it
Thunderclap none Track plays concurrently over all others
Heavy Rain Rain Track cross-fades with previous "rain" track to replace it
